question_content.barrons:question: The author of the passage objects to historical writing like that published in Américas because it

barrons:choices.barrons:choice: corroborates the findings of present-day experts in pre-Columbian archaeology
ignores the interplay between mysticism and realism in the Quechua belief system
emphasizes the importance of written records over non-literary forms of recordkeeping
uses figurative language instead of facts and figures as the basis for interpreting a culture
substitutes political for literary criteria in evaluating Quechua civilization

question_content.barrons:explanation:
uses figurative language instead of facts and figures as the basis for interpreting a culture

The author contrasts those historians who relied on metaphor and symbol (figurative language) to make their points with "their contemporaries who based their conclusions on archeological findings and on new interpretations of the quipu" (facts and figures). He objects to the formers’ writing because of its obscurity.

Corroborates the findings of present-day experts in pre-Columbian archaeology is incorrect. Nothing in the passage suggests that historical writing like the 1963 article published in Américas supports or corroborates the findings of present-day experts in pre-Columbian archaeology.

Ignores the interplay between mysticism and realism in the Quechua belief system is incorrect. Nothing in the passage suggests that historical writing like the 1963 article published in Américas disregards or ignores the interplay between mysticism and realism in the Quechua belief system.

Emphasizes the importance of written records over non-literary forms of recordkeeping is incorrect. Nothing in the passage suggests that historical writing like the 1963 article published in Américas places any emphasis on the importance of written records over non-literary forms of recordkeeping.

Substitutes political or literary criteria in evaluating Quechua civilization is incorrect. Nothing in the passage suggests that historical writing like the 1963 article published in Américas exchanges or substitutes political or literary criteria in evaluating Quechua civilization.
